3) No problem raised in any one class
session should remain unresolved, and
that resolution should occur in that
class session.
4) The teachers, both the television and
the classroom, must stress "similarity
of problem structures" as they occur,
and lead the student to insight by en¬
couraging identification among students,
so that they may have the opportunity
of working through failures to success.
5) The individual sessions must begin and
end the same way, at the same time, at
the same place in the text, for both
groups.
6) The "course" of instruction must begin
and end at the same time for both groups.
7) The technical problems of the television
studio "classroom" must be resolved in
such a way as to eliminate any possi¬
bility of the technology intruding into
the learning process. (The student must
be unaware of the involvement of tele¬
vision equipment.) If the classroom
